title: 3 Common Digestive Diseases: Symptoms, Causes, and When to Get Help

content: Digestive diseases affect millions of people every year and can range from mild, temporary discomfort to chronic, life-altering conditions. Understanding the signs, causes, and treatment options can help you get the right care sooner – and prevent complications down the road.
Here’s an overview of some of the most common digestive conditions, what they feel like, and how they’re typically managed.
1. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a chronic condition in which stomach acid flows back into the esophagus. It is common to think of heartburn or regurgitation; however, some people may have GERD but not heartburn. Other symptoms may include:
Why Does GERD Happen?

We have a ring of muscle at the bottom of the esophagus that acts as a valve to keep stomach contents from flowing back up into the esophagus. This is called the lower esophageal sphincter. When it becomes weak or relaxes too often, this can lead to worsening of symptoms. Common triggers include:
bullets: Problems swallowing or pain while swallowing
Symptoms of complications in the mouth, throat, or lungs, such as chronic cough or hoarseness
Discomfort from any of the mentioned symptoms that does not get better with over-the-counter medicines or lifestyle changes

content: Some factors that may increase risk of GERD include being pregnant, having a hiatal hernia (where the upper part of the stomach bulges up through the diaphragm and into the chest cavity), smoking or breathing secondhand smoke, and certain medications like benzodiazepines, sedatives, calcium channel blockers, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and tricyclic antidepressants.
During your visit with the gastroenterologist, some tests to assist in diagnosing GERD could be ordered, such as upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy or esophageal pH monitoring.
Treatment

Besides medical management like antacids, H2 blockers, or proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), getting support from a GI-specialized dietitian will help with lifestyle changes, identifying trigger foods, and managing other overlapping conditions and symptoms.
2. Disorders of Gut–Brain Interaction (DGBI)

A group of digestive conditions – previously known as “functional GI disorders” – involves problems with how the gut and brain communicate. DGBIs can include irritable bowel syndrome, reflux hypersensitivity, functional dyspepsia, or functional diarrhea/constipation. DGBIs affect up to 40% of the global population. In DGBI, the digestive tract appears normal on testing and scopes, but symptoms that cause significant distress persist.

sections.heading: Common Symptoms:
content: Why Does DGBI Occur?

DGBIs happen when the gut-brain axis (the communication system between the nervous system and digestive tract) becomes dysregulated. This leads to changes in gut motility, sensitivity, immune activity, and the microbiome – even though structural tests like colonoscopies or CT scans often look normal.
Tests Used to Diagnose DGBIs May Include:
Treatment

A personalized approach works best and can be done through working with a gastroenterologist and GI-specialized dietitian. Options may include diet changes (such as low FODMAP or fiber adjustments), gut-directed psychotherapy, stress reduction techniques, neuromodulators, probiotics, and medications targeted to specific symptoms like pain, constipation, or diarrhea.
bullets: Changes in bowel habits: Diarrhea, constipation, or a mix of both
Esophageal pH tests, including upper endoscopy with Bravo or pH impedance
Abdominal imaging tests, such as X-rays and ultrasound
Breath tests to look for malabsorption or overgrowth of bacteria
Motility tests to examine the function of different parts of the GI tract, including esophageal manometry or anorectal manometry

sections.heading: 3. Gastroenteritis (‘Stomach Flu’)
content: Gastroenteritis is an inflammation of the stomach and intestines, commonly called the "stomach flu," that causes symptoms like diarrhea, cramping, vomiting, and sometimes fever. It is typically caused by viruses, bacteria, or parasites and is often spread through contaminated food, water, or contact with an infected person. While it usually resolves on its own with rest and fluid replacement, severe cases can lead to dehydration.
Common Symptoms Include:
Tests

Most cases of gastroenteritis are mild and diagnosed based on your medical history and symptoms alone. But if symptoms are severe, last more than a few days, or there’s concern about dehydration or a bacterial infection, your doctor may order tests to find the cause and rule out other conditions. Stool and blood tests may be done. In rare cases, your doctor may use imaging studies to rule out other conditions that are more serious.

sections.heading: Treatment
content: Treatment for gastroenteritis focuses on preventing dehydration with oral rehydration solutions, clear fluids, and gradually reintroducing easy-to-digest foods. Most people recover at home with rest, hydration, and symptom relief medications like antiemetics; antibiotics are only needed for specific bacterial infections (not viral). Seek medical care if your symptoms are severe, prolonged, or accompanied by dehydration, high fever, or blood in your stool.

Early diagnosis can prevent long-term complications and improve your treatment outcomes.
The Bottom Line

Digestive diseases are common, but they’re highly treatable when caught early. Understanding your symptoms and talking with your health care team – including a GI specialist and a registered dietitian – can help you feel better, prevent flare-ups, and protect your long-term digestive health.
